thread.title: This US carrier is testing 5G with the help of Samsung and others | TechRadar
thread.title_full: This US carrier is testing 5G with the help of Samsung and others | TechRadar

author: Parker Wilhelm
title: This US carrier is testing 5G with the help of Samsung and others | TechRadar
text:
This US carrier is testing 5G with the help of Samsung and others This US carrier is testing 5G with the help of Samsung and others Verizon pushes the next step in wireless data Shares 
Verizon announced today that it is preparing customer trials of its newly built 5G network , testing the new generation of high-speed wireless data transfer in a series of different practical settings with the help of a handful of partner tech companies. 
The 11 markets included in the test span across the continental US, including Ann Arbor (MI), Atlanta (GA), Bernardsville (NJ), Brockton (MA), Dallas (TX), Denver (CO), Houston (TX), Miami (FL), Sacramento (CA), Seattle (WA), and Washington, D.C. 
Out of those 11 markets, five cities (New Jersey, Massachusetts, Texas, Washington, D.C., and "a fifth location in Michigan" - likely referring to Ann Arbor) are already planned to begin customer trials of the 5G network as soon as Q2 of this year, according to a press release from partner Samsung. The race to 5G 
Verizon is not alone in its testing endeavors, as the telecoms giant has partnered up with the likes of Ericsson, Intel, Qualcomm, Samsung, and more to provide technological assistance in testing its new network's effectiveness. 
“We are pleased about the progress made with partners like Samsung on advancing 5G technology commercially,” said Verizon executive vice president and chief information and technology architect, Roger Gurnani. “Delivering 5G to these pilot customers is an important step in assessing the business model and customer experience for delivering wireless broadband via 5G.” 
Though the road to building a new 5G standard is being paved - Qualcomm having just announced its fastest-yet gigabit modem for mobile devices earlier this week - it's still estimated that that 5G connectivity still has about another year or two before it becomes the new normal for smartphones.
